case_vignette: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for decreased exercise tolerance. Over the past four months, he has noticed progressively worsening shortness of breath while walking his dog. He also becomes short of breath when lying in bed at night. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 155/53 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitch, decrescendo murmur that occurs immediately after S2 and is heard best along the left sternal border. There is an S3 gallop. Carotid pulses are strong.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Cardiovascular System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing decreased ability to exercise and progressively worsening shortness of breath, especially when walking my dog and also while lying in bed at night.
How old are you?
I am 62 years old.
Do you have any history of heart problems?
As a patient, I can't provide medical history; I'm here to describe the symptoms I've been experiencing.
Understood. Do you have a family history of heart disease?
As a patient, I don't have any information on my family's medical history to share.
I understand. Are you currently taking any medications?
As a patient, I can't provide details about medications or treatments; I'm just here to discuss my symptoms.
I see. Have you experienced any chest pain or palpitations?
No, I haven't experienced any chest pain or palpitations.
**Final Diagnosis:** Congestive Heart Failure
